I think this is a good idea, but unfortunately it's framed as a British/brexit issue. However, the wider concept of a common EU visa / migration system is a compelling one. Harmonising the system to a common visa regime offers many advantages.
Allowing migrants who have been awarded a legal migration status in a country mobility and residency rights across the EU stops the "citizenship for sale" competition at a stroke.
A common visa regime prevents angst between EU countries accusing each other of being either "soft" on migrants or erecting "fortresses". 
Gives the EU a huge advantage in attracting skilled workers, researchers and artists by offering a much larger pool of options and opportunities. 
Benefits migrants by giving them access to the whole EU, giving them the best chances for improving their quality of life and finding a good home.

Under international law, the current definition of indigeneity is provided by the 1989 ILO Convention on Indigenous and Tribal Peoples. Under the Convention, indigenous communities may seek specific administrative, proprietary and cultural laws to protect the cohesion of their traditional identity and connection with the land they inhabit. Under Art. 1b, people of European ancestry meet the criteria of being  "indigenous on account of their descent from the populations which inhabited the country, or a geographical region to which the country belongs, at the time of [...] the establishment of present state boundaries and who, irrespective of their legal status, retain some or all of their own social, economic, cultural and political institutions." I.e. Europeans in Europe are indigenous akin to Australian Aboriginals, Canadian First Nations, Tibetans, Uyghurs, Maoris, etc. in their respective home regions, each subdivided into nations, tribes and clans.

"Green up to cool down"

The need to change our agriculture is imperious - a study just published estimated that up to 40% of greenhouse gas emissions worldwide come from the food system. This must change.

I support EU-wide implementation of Carbon tax. There are several challenges which will need to be addressed though.
1. The tax should be progressive per capita. This will ensure that we tax mostly overuse of resources and avoid increasing wealth inequality of the poor.
Imports need to be fairly taxed, otherwise we will harm local companies. Exports should not be exempted from taxation either, but I am unsure about how exactly we can ensure that we will not put exporting companies into huge disadvantage.
Every single source of pollution needs to be taxed correctly. E.g. biomass is at the moment considered carbon neutral. However in reality, it should be taxed as other non renewables such as coal and oil, due to its impact on ecosystems and slow regeneration.
Degradation of soil should be taxed. Biofuels and crops grown in an incorrect way degrade soil and release carbon stored in the soil into the air.
Utilized land area which is not kept as wild nature should be taxed.

This tax should not be applied only to internal market, but also to incoming imported goods. By the way, there's a quite successful European Citizens' Initiative proposing exactly this, called #StopGlobalWarming, you might wanna look it up :)

It should be payed out to every citizen of the EU. Those people with a lower CO2 footprint - typically lower income family - would greatly benefit from it and be incentiviced to invest in cleaner energy, heating etc.

Most experts agree that an EU-wide carbon tax would be an efficient way to curb our CO2 emissions. 
If no unanimity is possible within the 27 MS, why not seeking a multilateral agreement among the willing states? (Like Eurogroup, Schengen, etc)
In my point of view it will be essential to impose some compensatory levies on products from third countries to ensure that they will not have a competetive advantage. 
Eventually, the best solution would be a world wide agreement (as within OECD and like minded) such as the global minimum tax rate.

I don't agree. There are existing models, how to live with 100 percent renewables. It's not so difficult. The difficulty is in our brain & mindset. We're used to big power plants running on whatever sorts of fuel with lousy efficiency. We're used to produce energy centrally & distribute it through complicated & sophisticated networks. This is highly inefficient as most such power plants are gigantic steam engines which use a lot of water to stay cool. In case of nuclear power cooling is needed to prevent a melt down. And if water is not available because of drought or freezing or earth quake tsunami etc, these gigantic steam engines have either to shut down or will produce highly hazardous outcomes. 
Being gigantic steam engines means also that they are more of a heating than a power production. Both steam engines & combustion engines have in common that they produce more heat than movement or electricity. 
Th

There are whole regions which are completely energy autonome with wind energy, solar power & biogas - not only in developing countries, but in industrialised countries as well. It's not a question of technology, but just of mindset & innovative arrangement.
Where energy costs for consumers are high in combination with renewables, it's mostly due to political decisions & market set-up, not due to technical issues. Unfortunately old fashioned policies have made things very complicated. Where ever energy cooperations can play their part, things become much easier & more cost effective. If big companies have to deliver it all alone, things become difficult, complicated & costly, because their structures make it difficult to provide sophisticated setups for communities of small consumers. If they would concentrate on services for big consumers & let energy cooperations play their part in neighbourhoods, this would work much better. The settings would be more to the point.

I know, some people who don't know much about renewables are quite anxious to lose comfort & control. But even a conservative politician like Peter Altmaier said about 10 years ago that 100% renewables are technically feasible. It's not a question of technology but of intelligent management & policies.
I know, some birds die from windmills, but many more from cats & glass facades. Bird experts recommend, not to build wind farms where birds are crossing on their way south or north, because they have to bypass the farm & lose time & energy. They also recommend not to build wind farms near the nests of big predator birds, because they tend to be less focused on the windmills in this context. But they don't generally oppose windmills. This only happens with people who have no proper information. And to be against PV in my opinion is simply irrational. 
Insects also die by windmills sometimes, but much more often from hunger, birds or herbicides, insecticides etc.
.

So, if you want to save birds, you perhaps should think about domesticared cats & make modern buildings more bird friendly. If you want to save insects, look at the way of land use & agriculture & create insect friendly gardens. The birds will love them, too ;).

About people & windmills. Experience tells us that people who own windmills like them. Communities who own their windmills & get the profits from the windmills locally, support them. Communities who have to deal with big companies, just coming, building up their wind farms without any respect for the locals, heavily dislike the them.
If a big company comes & wants to build up a offshore wind farm where life beneath the water surface is widely undisturbed, it might be not the best idea, because offshore wind farms which are stable & not floating, need some major construction efforts.
So keep nature in mind & let the locals decide & participate. It doesn't make sense to just focus on renewable energy without the social & environmental issues around.

The problem is that people who are against PV & windmills mostly think of energy as a commodity, provided by big companies. People who favour renewables often have completely different experiences. They think of energy as a human right & free energy production as a human right. They know how to produce, store & dissipate renewable energy themselves. They experiment with different forms & setups. Or they have family members, friends, colleagues who do so. Some also know how to equippe big housing or business buildings with renewables. Some have experience with semipermeable greenhouse glass to collect sunlight while underneath plants are growing. Some know agro-pv where PV is designed to protect the plants beneath. Just to plaster big fields with PV is the least intelligent way to do it ;).

Banning the cultivation of spawning for energy purposes is a step in the right direction. Only the recovery of waste should be encouraged. For example, burning straw after growing crops or using manure in biogas plants. Growing crops for energy purposes carries a greater burden on the environment (pesticides, soil compaction and tillage costs). It is more appropriate to afforest these areas. The impact on biodiversity and the quality of the environment will be higher.

Some biofuels shouldn't be scaled up. Those which compete with food production, those which encourage deforestation... Soy, corn, sugar cane, rapeseed and palm oil are probably not sustainable in the long term. Biofuels made from wood chippings are only as sustainable as the forestry industry that produces them.
However, there are other biofuels which have fewer side effects. Algae-sourced biofuels, fuels generated from sewage & waste gases, for example. Algae do not compete with food production and don't require deforestation. Sewage & waste sourced methane is a more powerful greenhouse gas than CO2 if it is not collected & used as biofuel. 
Fossil-sourced natural gas, on the other hand, is as harmful as coal or oil. If it is sourced from fossil fuels, natural gas produces a net increase in CO2 in the atmosphere when burned. It is not suitable as a sustainable or bridging technology. Biofuel methane, on the other hand, is a zero sum game: it does not add new CO2.

As everyone speaks about various pros and cons, I just want to remind some facts: nuclear power  provides 26% of all electricity in the EU, which at the same time is 48% of all low-carbon electricity in the European Union. Let that sink in: nuclear power provides half of the low-carbon electricity in the EU (EuroStat 2021). Worldwide, nuclear power has prevented emissions of 240 billion tonnes of CO2, and prevented 1.8 million lives due to prevented air pollution (Kharecha, Hansen 2013). Nuclear power is safe - there are over 400 nuclear power plants globally, most of which have operated with no issues for the last 40 years, providing 24/7 electricity and preventing pollution and CO2 emissions. In terms of safety, including all accidents and pollution, nuclear power has caused 0.07 deaths/TWh, which is 40x less than natural gas and comparable with wind power (OurWorldInData 2021). Nuclear power takes little space, and unlike wind and solar works 24/7 and 7 years to build on average.

People highlight various risks, but any generation technology comes with risks: the largest electricity-related disaster (Banquiao dam in 1976) took lives of 200'000 people (!) or just recently 70 people in Russia, but nobody talks about hydropower being "deadly" or complaining about states providing insurance for such massive projects, because it happens for all projects of such scale. In the UK since 2015 there were over 80 PV-related fires, at least 1/4 of which were actual solar panels catching fire, releasing toxic smoke and contaminating the ground with cadmium. There is no generation technology that comes with zero risks, and this is why we need to look at objective scientific indicators. If you are interested, I recommend "Life Cycle Assessment of Electricity Generation Options" published by UNECE in 2021, as it's probably the most comprehensive analysis of environmental impact of all electricity sources, and nuclear comes out surprisingly well.

Agreed.  
There are several aspects that need to be addressed in order to move to a circular economy, but the main topic of this thread, education, is very important. If everybody understands the necessity of having a circular economy and already starts changing the way they consume wherever they can right now, then it will be much more attractive for companies to adapt.
There has to be a general awareness that the real price of throw-away products and mass-produced foods is paid in the longer run and that continuing down the current path will lead to more problems than having to adjust ones consumer behavior.  
So to be specific:
- there should be a permanent information campaign (TV, Youtube, cinema, online adds)
- the EU should do what they can to encourage classes on "Sustainable Life on Earth" in schools, so all levels of income are reached.
- there could be a website explaining the full chain of a wasteful lifestyle and showing what the EU is doing to help change this.

I think that one of the key points about educating a general population on a circular economy also involves making people understand that sometimes the clean way is not the easy way or the most comfortable way. A more circular economy will sometimes (not always of course) mean consumer objects that are not optimized for consumer confort but for end-of-life management. As an example, after having done some research on the topic of smartphones, I believe that we will not manage to make this industry sustainable enough without compromising slightly on things like phone thinness, waterproofing, etc. But if we could get people to realize that at least 90% of them don't need a phone as optimized as they have now then the change would be easier.

I generally agree. More information is required & should be spread more widely. 
To have a real plan, communicate properly, help people understand what's actually at stake & support them doing the right thing, helps greatly. But it's just part of the game.
Another part is creating contexts where sustainability is already implemented, like in plus energy housing areas where all energy needed for electricity, heating and mobility is locally produced & renewable. Water is locally treated into high quality drinking water. Electric vehicles are available if inhabitants want it. Possibilities to grow own crops are available, if wanted. Businesses, local services etc.
If we create such environments which are inherently sustainable, it's not very costly. It just needs knowledge, proper planning & smart investment.
Another pilar seems to me taxation. One quite complex, but extremely rewarding possibility would be a sustainability tax for all products from inside and outside the EU.

I like this, but I would solve it a bit differently. 
Currently all production and consumption is subsidized unintentionally. Currently, the price of the product doesn't include cost of mitigating damage done to the environment by extraction, production and disposal of said product.
Imagine if every company would have to pay the full cost of:
* using a finite resource
* restoring natural ecosystem in places where the extraction happened (through reforestation, reseeding native flora and restoring fauna and it's habitat)
* reversing environmental impact of manufacturing and logistics (scrubbing CO2, filtering waste water, etc)
* disposing of the packaging and product waste in it's entirety (which would obviously be significantly higher for plastics than for biodegradable materials)
Then that would be the full cost of the product. Yes, the standard of citizens would drop in short term, but cost savings would be a huge motivation for innovation of said companies.

I totally agree. Our production system is subsidizing climate change as well as the pollution and destruction of the planet. If all costs, including CO2 emissions of the production, the extraction of ressources and its consequences for the region (environment and humans), ecosystem damage and restorage, recycling of the waste and so on and so forth would be monetarised and internalised in the costs of the products, many of our problems would be solved. It would simply make the more environmentally friendly products cheaper then the others and their production  economically smarter. In a capitalist system in which all environmental and social and health costs of everybody affected would be internalised in the pricing of a product, the market could solve most problems.

This author's suggestions are based on wrong assumptions. 
By saying that 95% of climate change was not been man made he might be referring to the overall carbon cycle. 
Before industrialisation started, the amount of carbon that was released into the air (e.g. by natural forest fires) and extracted from the air (e.g. by moores, trees and oceans) have been in perfect balance. The amount of carbon particles in the air have not changed significantly over very long time frames. This would be the carbon cycle. 
Now, if you consider a perfectly balanced scale, you can imagine how adding a tiny amount of weight to one side will bring the system severely out of balance. If you consider a scale being in balance with 100g on each side, and now you add 10g to one side (that would be adding 5% to the system), the system would tip over. And every reasonable person would agree, that 100% of the cause for the system tipping would be you introducing those extra 5% to the system.

Climate change is due to 95% to human influence* (natural sources of variability almost did not change over the past 100 years, still, the temperature increased faster than ever --> due to human emissions of greenhouse gases)

This suggestion has nothing to do with the environment or climate change. I have no opinion about whether hemp production and CBD are good or bad for society, and I'm sure there are reactionary governments acting irrationally and unfairly, but I don't see any environmental / climate change related argument here, nor do I see any reason why the EU should fund research into uses for hemp.

Henry Ford was the first to use cannabis to make automotive body parts, in conjunction with other crops. Much of this technology is pushed aside or vilified by the Oil and Forestry industries. Hemp / Cannabis is easily grown in most parts of the world and does not need the water, pesticides, or other chemicals needed by other plants, like cotton or flax...hence the nickname "Weed". It can be used for building materials, and a plethora of other every day products, just do a search NOT on Google, and you will have plenty of information. Duck Duck Go is a good non-biased search engine. And if anyone is interested in the medical studies on cannabis, look up Granny Storm Crow's List. It includes thousands of research studies. Personally I believe that Cannabis has been kept illegal in much of the USA in order to maintain legalized slavery, but that's off topic here.  Hemp / Cannabis could make a huge difference in the production of everything from homes and vehicles to biodegradable bags.

I am not a vegetarian, but I have been shifting my dietary habits away from meat for a few years now, purely because of the industry's impact on the environment.  At the moment, we are in a perverse situation, where many veggie alternatives are more expensive than their non-veggie (subsidised) counterparts. So the first thing that the EU can and should do is to change its Common Agricultural Policy. Products where less harmful alternatives exist should not be subsidised as they are now. There should be carbon taxes applied to foods, priced so that plant-based alternatives are always cheaper than their animal-based counterparts. Industrial animal farming should be curtailed by setting meaningful minimum standards for animal welfare - the current standards are grotesque and obscene. There should be CO2-labels on all food products, so consumers can make informed decisions. Finally, more research into vegetarian alternatives (incl. cultured meats) should be funded by the EU.

It's tempting to think so, but still, I. I'm not happy with such a suggestion. Why?
Development of climate on earth is not a game like TerraGenesis. Earth is the only place that we have right now. And as you rightly confirm with your statement, we don't have these technologies right now,but we already know - if we don't greatly ignore - by the means of available scientific evidence that we are on the way to quit the boundaries of the planet which support human existence. We are already more or less out of frame, not only concerning the question of climate, but as well the question of water cycles, soil depletion and others. As we are actually starting to broadly adopt climate thinking, we are already terribly late and running out of time. If we want to have a comfortable living on earth, we should change the setup of our societies, economies and lives asap. Best within the next 10 years.

We are facing sea level rise which already swallows land, puts threat on municipalities & states. We face already droughts, water scarcity & heavy rains in alternating patterns all around the world, putting farmers & citizens likewise at risk in both cases. We have wildfires all around the world which heat up & spread in ways, firefighters never had seen before. We are losing big amounts of arable soil worldwide on a yearly basis due to desertification, soil depletion & construction of buildings & infrastructure. Our oceans are acidified & stratified with death zones spreading. At the same time they are oberfished, depleted of plancton & polluted both by plastic & microplastic. We have a exponentially growing world economy which is bound to grow under the current system, but in the same time bound to deplete & ravage resources ever faster in order to grow, a world economy the more vulnerable & prone to fail, the more it grows. And all these things are not developing independently.

All these problems are evolving together, with climate being only part of the picture. They all are intertwined & tend to reinforce each other.
Maybe, while you are dreaming of an ideally comfortable climate for your own country & hoping for a genius technology to make it happen, your nice little country might be overrun by people who had no choice to dream & hope, but have to move & to fight in order to survive. Or the nice economy that seems so stable & self-understood to you that you never dared to doubt it might be quite the same tomorrow, is going to falter, because part of the world is crumbling. 
As it is your right to dream while action would be necessary. I just want to put a warning post in place because this is not private reasoning, but multilayered discussion.

Nuclear power plants are actually gigantic steam engines with a lousy efficiency. A technology from the 19th century combined with one of the 20th century. They primarily function as a heating & only secondarily produce electricity. That's maximum waste of resources. 
Depending on the specific technology they use masses of water for cooling. In case of water scarcity they have to shut down partially or completely. For example in looong summer 2018 when they had to do so to prevent overheated ecosystems and classical meltdown.
Nuclear power plants are expensive in building, use masses of concrete as one of the least sustainable building materials on earth. Which in this case cannot even be recycled because every nuclear waste - not only the highly contaminated - has to go underground. On a time scale larger than all known human civilizations together! 
As nuclear power plants are costly to build and evenly costly to dismantle, they need to run on full capacity as much as possible.

Technology also requires them to be mostly run on full capacity. They dislike fast changes as necessary in cooperation with renewable energy. So running as many as possible nuclear power plants actually means to make renewable energy less possible because from all non renewables they are the least viable in combination.
We don't lack sources for renewable energy. We just need crippling legislation to be put aside, so that citizens can produce their own energy. The potential is enormous.
We also don't need to wait for masses of batteries to come. It's a fairy tale. The first 100 % renewable energy run & 100% ind√©pendant region, I know, started in the 1970s! They were completely independent, before any viable batteries were available. The simple solution they chose: Hot water storage. Easy to set up, use & maintain, but still half illegal in some places.
They used by heat from biogas plants to boil the water. Then they could use the water, either for heating or to provide electricity

They also used surplus electricity from wind mills to boil the water. So, these simple hot water storages were double input (heat and electricity) and double output (heat and electricity). 
This is a viable option, even without batteries. Though a few batteries even make the system more efficient.
There are a whole bunch of concepts and technologies available for every setting you want. But there are also crippling laws in place that hinder people to come together and make their own energy. Many do & many try. But few meet their whole potential due to limitations from legislation.
Nuclear power plants do little to boost local economy because most of the money is made by transnational companies, the only entities except state, which are able to build & run them. Local wind mills or solar power owned by citizens in contrary have done a lot to develop left behind rural areas - without dangerous fuels & waste which by now is mostly stored close to the power plants.

The EU should ensure a just transition by making sure that : 
- There is adequate social protection and training/re-skilling/upkilling programmes to accompany workers and people currently excluded from the labour market during the transition. 
- There are comprehensive industrial strategies and just transition plans in place to anticipate changes ahead as well as maintain and create sustainable quality jobs in affected regions
- There is an effective social dialogue and a strong participation of workers at each stage of the process. 
- Proper financing is guaranteed through solidarity mechanisms in the EU budget, through fair and effective taxation and through adequate policies from the EIB and ECB.

I fully agree that research on aging as well as interventions to keep people young and healthy should be at the heart of the European Union's health priorities.
The coronavirus shows us very clearly, the elderly are in poorer health than the young and are more vulnerable to viral diseases such as covid.
Therefore, a treatment capable of maintaining or restoring the elderly to a youthful state will protect both from age-related diseases, but also from future pandemics like the coronavirus, which will be extremely beneficial for the economy, because it will reduce government health spending !

I also think that anti-aging research should be supported by the European Union. The process of aging and the suffering and mental and physical decay that come with it strip people of their dignity and take away their freedom.
In my opinion rejuvenation can and will be a medical reality within the next several decades. We should make sure today that everyone has access to such treatments and that we are not missing out on this possibility as a society.

The idea of prevention being better than a cure is nothing new or revolutionary. Rejuvenation therapies would be one of the greatest steps humanity has ever taken, with one of the many benefits including huge savings on heath care costs in the elderly. It is about time this received more focus and funding than the woeful attention organisations currently exploring this technology are getting.

People might think of anti-aging or reversing aging as science fiction, but real research and progress is being made in the field. Look at the work done by researchers such as Aubrey De Grey, and David Sinclair.
Aging reversal is achievable, and desirable for everyone.
I believe longevity is essential to the well being of our society and the future of humanity altogether. It's not a matter of if it happen but when and the sooner the better for everyone.
This is definitely the most important and underrated thing this century

However, I don't think it would be good for the whole of society (or the planet) if ageing and mortality were stopped. Virtually every sphere of life - the political, the economical, the ecological, the cultural - would suffer. Would anti-aging be a luxury for the super rich? Would people have to work until they are 100 years old? Would people be discouraged from having children so that there is enough living space (and food and other resources) for all the people living for centuries? Would people remain physically young, but continue to age and decay mentally? Sometimes, what is best for the individual (not aging, living with a good quality of life, forever) is not what is best for mankind.

Our joint objective should be to slow down, stop or reverse aging completely and it is possible. The EU has to simply cannot miss this economic chance and has to become a world wide leader in these fields to be able to fight for reasonable ethics and politics concerning longevity, if not, it will come anyway, only that Europe then won't have any influence on these questions in the future.

Whatever the EU does, the research will go on in other countries. The potential business is just too big for it to stop. Europe can just not miss such a train.  And what will be more expensive: anti aging research and future treatment or current cost to take care of the elderly?

I fully agree that research on aging as well as interventions to keep people young and healthy should be at the heart of the European Union's health priorities.

These 4 elements are exactly what we need to achieve the noble goal of the highest level of health for all.

If we find a way to conquer aging, we will be able to cut down on healthcare costs by preventing the secondary diseases it causes. Therefore investments in anti-aging technology will pay off in the long-run.
The economical and societal benefits of healthy longevity and extension of healthspan are so overwhelming that it should be on the top of the list of priorities the EU should be focusing on.

Making research into this field a top priority could also allow Europe to become a leader in a potentially immensly impactful field.

I am sorry, P√©ter Henning, but I do not agree with you and with the last decision of the European Parliament on daylight saving time changing. Having to change the time twice a year and synchronising that change it in all the countries of the Union (even with time zones that do not perfectly reflect the legal order) has two major advantages:
1) Having the same time in most of the Union‚Äôs countries helps reducing significant administrative difficulties: Let us imagine how difficult it would be to make goods and people travel from one country to another if the time (and therefore the timetables of the transportations) would change at each border. ...their activities, so why would they need to have an astronomically correct hour? Wanting to exaggerate the speech to better explain my point of view I could tell you that having an astronomically correct hour would have to be corrected by a few seconds each kilometer, which will agree with me that it is organizationally absurd.
2) Imposing the time change allow to have more hours of light in summer, which gives an energy saving. I know that some studies say that savings would be minimal, but we must consider the growing European energy dependence on photovoltaics: We humans consume more electricity when we are awake, the photovoltaic gives a good availability of energy but only during the day and is difficult to store, to overlap the moment of energy availability given by photovoltaics (the hours of light) with the moment in which citizens have the most energy needs I think it can eventually save more energy in the future.

... a single global timezone. After all, do we really need an astronomically correct hour, given that the regulation of daily life according to the time is conventional? A world time zone would solve those organizational problems I mentioned above: Do you know how complex the change is now in the world given the various time zones and the various time changes of today which take place only in some countries, on different days and (CONTINUE...)

...in a different way between the northern hemisphere and the southern hemisphere? Support for a stronger role of the EU in health. Europe is currently failing its citizens when it comes to health, in particular in cancer where patients often depend on the access to expensive medicines for a chance to survive. The lack of coordination between MS- difference in Early Access, Clinical Trials, off-label drug usage and experimental medicine mean that the chances to survive differ dramatically between even neighbouring countries. From an EU citizen's perspective, this is unacceptable. We have shown with COVID that we are able to organise joint procurements of medicines and people should be free to move in Europe without having to fear inferior healthcare systems.

Thank you for sharing your idea on the expansion of the EU's health competences. The current division of health competences between the EU and its Member States limits the ability to act together in the field of health. 
The European Health Union Initiative puts forward a similar proposal to expand EU health competences. Strengthening EU powers in health will in turn strengthen powers of health actors in Member States.
You can find the proposed treaty change and more background information here: https://europeanhealthunion.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Treaty-changeposition-paperfinal.pdf
You can find and sign the European Health Union Manifesto here: https://europeanhealthunion.eu/

Young people may choose not to be exploited. My main problem with unpaid internships is that young people choose them, because there is not enough entry level paid jobs out there. Banning the practice will not change the underlying problem one bit. 
Reforms in the economy and education are the answer to your grievance, but those may not be solved by brute government force.
Schools in Germany often have internship as parts of the schedule. No company would take students like that as interns if they had to pay them.

I am for ban for the internships which does not provide additional education and skills building, which are low level jobs with no growth propspects. Such internships should be paid definitely.
But I am against ban for unpaid internships which provide other benefits - continuing education, mentoring, experience, skills building, etc. upon which the highly paid job can be acquired in the future.
The high-quality unpaid internships has impact on inequality - currently they put poor people in disadvantage and hence they are factor for sustaining poverty trap. That is not right. But it can be solved by Unconditional Basic Income/Unconditional Dividend which provides financial background for everyone for entering into skills building project - by volunteering, by having unpaid internships, but having own pet projects etc.
So - the integral growth of person - that is available to everyone practically -  and his/her skills should be the focus of policy.

This is a ridiculous proposition. No one is forcing you to take an unpaid internship. If companies are forced to pay for interns many just wont take any. which is a missed opportunity for people learning skills.
this is also difficult to regulate. will you ban voluntary work too? if not, what's the legal difference.
Why should we not have the freedom to work as a free intern for a company if we want to? how is this a good idea? this is just a restriction of freedom of choice.

Stop doing interns after your second unpaid job.

This idea is good in what it wants to achieve but lacks a basis in economics. Salaries (or the price of labour) is determined by scarcity - there is an equilibrium between demand and supply. Raising the price of labour above that equilibrium is great for the people that are employed, but does mean that the demand of labour is reduced - companies are only willing to spend so much on labour.

There is quite a lot on the way - and - a lot is already there. Recently, some renowned experts have put forth a paper stating that with the existing technology we can reach 100 % renewable energy in electric power supply as soon as 2030 and in the building sector & mobility in 2035. These are people who work in the sector for decades.
One of the first energy independent regions in Europe started to develop in the 1970s! They were completely autonomous before any batteries were available. Why? Simply because they used hot water energy storage. This is incredibly cheap and easy to install, handle & maintain, but in some places still half illegal.
They used the heat of their biogas plant to boil water that easily can be stored. They also used the surplus of windenergy to boil water. Then they could use the hot water either to heat the buildings or to make electricity.
We have all technology in place to create 100% renewable energy regions. It's our mindset that makes it difficult.

Of course, there is still a lot of possible improvement in the pipeline, but we definitely don't have to wait for some genius new technology to start.
Why am I so definitely against this proposal though it sounds so reasonable and helpful? I'm definitely against the notion that we'll have to wait for a new genius industrial technology to show up to even think of starting proper transformation. In my opinion, the opposite is true: We have to start right now with what we have & by the way develope better concepts how to use all the technology & methods already available optimately. And for me, nuclear energy which is - by the way - relaunched with this proposal, is definitely not part of the game, not even in the modular mininuke version of Mr Gates. There are people who know much more about renewable energy than Mr Gates & completely energy independent who hate that book because of this crap.

Why no nuclear power plants?
Nuclear power plants are gigantic steam engines with a deadly dangerous fuel. Steam engines are a technology from the 19th century with incredibly lousy efficiency.. Recently I read something about 20%. Both nuclear & cole fired plants are much better in producing heat than electricity, though cole fired plants are more efficient. As they produce first heat and only second electricity, they need amazing amounts of water to cool. In a time with increasing heat & water stress in ecosystems & societies, this might not be the most intelligent path to follow.
Just as an example: When in loooong summer 2018 big rivers fell short of water, nuclear power plants had to partly or completely shut down, to avoid both overheating of the ecosystems & meltdown inside.
Nuclear power plants are incredibly energy consuming both in construction & in dismantling. The building materials are maximum unsustainable & cannot be reused afterwards. Same to the fuel elements.

Nuclear power plants are technically & financially not built for coexistence with renewable energy because they need to run on full capacity as much as possible. First for amortisation of the costs & in order to make money, second because their technical setup doesn't support quick changes. The mininuke plants, suggested by Bill Gates are said to be more flexible, but I haven't heard or read anything of real prototypes being examined.
They might be less costy if mass produced. But this would mean that we have to plaster the world with them to make them cheap & convenient. And additionally we have to wait for them to save our planet. That's ridiculous & dangerous.
Experts expect them not to be essentially safer than the big ones, but less controllable. I'm not happy with such proposals.

I agree that a common language is necessary to build a stronger European Union.
However, in my view, a better common language would be a democratic and fair language, one that relates to Europe's identity, history and culture, and is also still present in schools, monuments, churches, etc. This language is Latin -- our common language for 2000 years.

1.a) In the perception of the citizens, we are not at the level of European unity and solidarity which is necessary for this, to not seem like a foreign imposition.
1.b) Rightfully, each member state already decide their own policy on wealth redistribution and welfare for their citizens.
UBI potentially incentivizes unwanted behavior/effects
2.a) A surge in children, especially in the lower classes. Since each child will earn income for the family, and thereby incentivize having children.
2.b) Reduced incentive to work and satisfy consumer demand.
2.c) There is no way to finance this that isn't prohibitively expensive for the Member States or doesn't cause massive credit expansion and / or inflation.

Two important things the central bank needs to watch out for:
The stock market valuation must adjust (30 - 70 %) every 7 to 10 years, so that the poor on the "coward side" of the consolidated banks balance sheet never get the idea to switch into the assets held by the "rich and daring". The stock market valuation must never crash to such a level (70 - 100% loss) that banks will be forced to sell the assets margined by the rich and hand them to the poor in a great depression fire-sale or revolution.

The idea seems to be based on a concept similar to social businesses. Social businesses are not for profit enterprises that serve the society or local communities, make enough money to sustain themselves, but by definition do not try to make more money than necessary to develop their products and services and their own operations. They also by definition do not offer revenues to lenders. This is a disadvantage under the current rules of economy where businesses are supposed to make substantial gains for their stakeholders. 
But as these businesses fill in a gap to solve social and environmental problems which can not be addressed by for profit companies, state or charity, they depend on legislation to shield them from abuse and state grants or private initiative to get the money to start and sometimes to expand. So in the interest of government, society and citizens it's necessary to introduce new rules and create adequate funds.

To create such rules and funds does not impose socialism on the society, but in contrary give entrepreneurs the opportunity to choose the way they want to operate their business instead of forcing them to deliver ever greater revenues and forget about every other aim they might have.

I absolutely agree that there must be an urgent tax reform in the EU. It is important that these tax loopholes and "tax sweetheart" deals be called out and closed. I read in an article recently that Apple was paying an effective tax rate of 1% for many years in Ireland. In 2014, it was uncovered that they actually paid a tax rate in the order of 0.005%, on the revenues generated in other jurisdictions. It is time that these multinationals start paying their fair share, where they generate their revenues, not in the jurisdictions where they decide to be domiciled for fiscal purposes. This is really obscene. These multinationals, on aggregate, end up paying less than the common citizen. Country by country reporting is a step in the right direction. And yes, it is certain that states will fight this. One way is to change the way fiscal matters are voted on, instead of unanimity in the European Council; these are voted by Quantitative Majority Voting in the European Parliament.

The fiscal union is a very interesting proposal that has been in some progressive circles for a few years now. I think it would also require an electoral reform. I wrote a text, one year ago, where I talked a bit about this in the context of the Eurobonds, at the time. If you are interested, please check it: https://diem25.org/without-eurobonds-the-politics-of-revanchism-is-back/

I agree wholeheartedly with the completion of the fiscal union. The current taxes and levies being discussed at the moment, such as the digital levy, could and should be used as instruments to supplement EU budget contributions and should be channelled in the creation of jobs and building and improving infrastructure.
I also agree that there is an urgent need for electoral reform. Fiscal matters cannot continue to be decided based on unanimity through the European Council.
Treaty changes are urgently needed, to allow these matters to be decided based on Quantitative Majority Voting in the European Parliament. Fiscal reform, decided at Council level, where all 27 must agree will never work, as there are certain, shall we say "business friendly" states that will always veto this. I feel that this is an area where treaty changes are urgently needed.

You have very outdated view on regulation. Regulation can be necessary because of the complexity of how we use our common resources, climate change, health issues and consumer protection. The good news is that regulation can be handled and the compliance can be implement using artificial intelligence.
All this is emerging, but scientists are working on the systems how the accounting systems can be generated from the law and how the law can be automatically translated into formal expressions in the appropriate logical format. In fact, already whole GDPR regulation has been formally translated into mathematical expressions using specialized formalization of natural language grammar.
Similar situation is with industrial system. Many systems - robotic systems, building designs etc. are verified against formal specifications and it should be possible to transform legal norms into just additional formal specifications.
So, I invite You to focus on the current technologies.

Also it's difficult to meet friends who work a different schedule than you.
Therefore i would vouch for a step in the opposite direction, increasing the bonuses of workers in nightshifts, so that companies focus on automating these jobs first.

This proposal is filled with misinformation, misunderstanding, and plain stupid ideas:
1.- "But recently a wave of socialism, and socialist policies have been infiltrating in the EU, increasing taxes, increasing government spending and debt, putting more regulatory pressure on businesses and entrepreneurs"
This affirmation is half wrong. According to OECD data [1], the tax burden in European Countries hasn't changed much since 1990. The "wave of socialism and socialist policies" may have happened 80 years ago, when governments created social healthcare, public pension schemes, and social security.
2.- There is not an "advance of Marxism Socialism and leftist ideology". All relevant European SocialDemocrat parties abandoned Marxism during the XX century. In the EU parliament, more than 400 MEPs are from conservative or liberal parties; more than 200 are center-left, and the rest, a mix of nationalist, regionalist and other ideologies.

3.- Buying territory from Russia? Last month the Russian military was moving troops on the Ukrainian border, menacing allied territories. If even diplomatic relations are difficult, literally buying parts of the country is impossible.
4.- Resettling Europeans in bought land? And what would you do with the people living there? That would create armed conflicts around the world. Colonialism stopped working in the XX century (if it ever worked in the first place) and the cost of moving millions of people would be incredible. Not even talking about who would sell land to Europe. There are thousands of empty towns in Europe that can be resettled easier and cheaper.
And again, you talk about "government intervention" but in the next line, you propose the EU to buy land and move people there (something that would take years and trillions of public funds). Isn't it easier to work with other governments, settle FTA and work with other democratic governments, than creating a Colonial Empire?

Capitalism and free market indeed created western wealth. However the interesting question then is: who benefited from this wealth ? Without some sort of regulation and control from the State, companies will continue what they do best, increase profit without any concern for environmental and social matters.
A free market is a market where the dirtiest company is the winner and the comapny with some integrity is deemed as "ineficient". The catastrophic consequeces of a total unregulation can be seen with Thatcher and Reagan. Regulations and input from ALL stakeholders (citizens through the government, workers through unions, ...) is needed to develop an economy that is not obsessed with growth at all costs. And contrary to what your idea seems to imply, this form of control does not need to be a marxist dictatorship of the proletariat.
And by the way I won't mention that "buying back land" and "resettling europeans" in other continents to "develop them" sounds quite colonial to me...

Homosexuals deserve the exact same rights as any other citizen. But no extra rights.

To respond some of your proposals:
Introducing an 'internal refugee program': Not even the external refugee program is resolved by the EU, the Community should focus more on that. On the other hand, the freedom of movement allows everyone to live and work in another member state.
Your proposal number 4, about the European Parliament: The national governments are elected by the people and are not accountable to the European Parliament. It is a proposal where the question of sovereignty arises: the EU should avoid interfering in national issues where it does not have a right to do so.

This is an extremist position that the OP arrives at from a completely fallacious premise.
There are no "Women, LGBT rights". These things simply do not exists anywhere in national or international law.
There are human rights - those are ennumerated in international human rights declartions, signed and ratified by sovereign states. There are no "human rights" beyond those written into these documents. There is no "human right to abortion". There is  no "human right to homosexual marriage.
There are also civil rights - these stem from the rights provided for and enforced by the states, and enshrined in the constitution or other acts of the legislatures.
All too often we see this gaslighting when biased people, motivated by ideological fervour make up "rights" out of wholecloth and condemn the "violation" of such non-existent "rights". These attempts are always dishonest, and do nothing for European Unity. Infact, they contribute to the current crisis of the EU.

Today, all end user devices are controlled by OSs and software, so they all are susceptible to malicious software and hence insecure. No matter how much effort is put into endpoint security, hacking those end user devices will always be possible. Also, most cyberattacks against IT systems are initiated via phishing mails compromising attached PCs.
We need to reintroduce hardware-controlled end user devices that are not susceptible to malware. Unlike the old terminals used in the past, they should support todays needs such as graphics, multimedia, multiple windows and videoconferencing. This is technically feasible, developing such secure devices will create a good market for European vendors. The EU should define a category for such secure devices, and make those mandatory for critical applications.
This will break many existing dependencies (e.g. on Windows) as those secure devices are inherently cloud/edge oriented and do work with new portal software, preferably in open source.

A good way to ensure a President of the Commission who is actually supported by a broad majority of citizens is by directly electing them via STV (Single Transferable Vote), which is a preferential voting system in which you rank your choices according to preference. This system ensures that all candidates have an actual chance of winning and not just the two major ones (which is the case in the two-round system) and it also makes it less likely that extreme candidates or candidates that are only supported by a plurality but not the majority of citizens is elected. 
Presently, the President of Ireland is elected this way, so if you would like to learn more about how this system works, do a quick internet search on Irish presidential elections.

I can understand the impulse, but I agree with many of the people here talking about how a parliamentary system is generally a better idea. Mostly because of the direct accountability to the legislature. The systems which score best on the democracy index tend to be parliamentary systems (you have to go down to place 11, Taiwan, to find find the first semi-presidential system).
But I'd also like to add to that that presidential systems are more prone to either deadlock or overreach. Because in a parliamentary system the legislature and the executive will always be controlled by the same party, whereas in a presidential system the president and legislatures may be of different parties. This can lead to one trying to stonewall the other or one grabbing all the power to try to get stuff done.

I strongly disagree that English should become the "officiel common language" of Europe, and in fact I even think English should no longer be used as the main working language in the European institutions.
In my view, a better common language would be one that relates to Europe's identity, history and culture, and is also still present in schools, monuments, churches, etc. This language is Latin -- our common language for 2000 years.
Classical Latin is of course a bit difficult to learn. However, a European initiative (led by the Latina Academia: https://latina.ac/en/) has resurrected Latin in a modern form, called "Modern Latin". It is important to note that Modern Latin is very easy to learn (i.e. you can be fluent in a year) and it is a truly European language, and as such would be a great initiative to unite European citizens and reinforce democracy.
Modern Latin would provide fairness and equality among European citizens.

I am Italian and I am working as a researcher in Belgium. I can't speak Dutch nor French. It is very common in our sector. We don't speak the local language because our contracts are really short and our work require frequent relocations. Most often you relocate in another EU countries.
We communicate in English and this works perfectly. But all administrative matters are a real pain. 
Making English official as a second language would make our life easier. And it will not make a huge difference since (e. g. here in Flanders) English is already an unofficial language that most people can speak. 
 Many other sectors do not share with the research sector the benefit of having English as (one of, together with the official languages) working language, creating a huge linguistic barrier to a unique, fluid job market.
I am a supporter of linguistic diversity. But this does not prevent from having a unique second official language to fight existing and important linguistic barriers.

The Spitzenkandidat method is a bad idea, and should be buried for two reasons.
First, there is no guarantee that the candidate is elected in his home country prior to the election, even if his group were to win in an European level. I think that the proponents of the Spitzenkandidat system have failed to take into account that a lot of countries, like Finland for example, choose the MPs with an open party list, and there is no guarantee that any candidate will make it to the top of the list. To avoid this, the parties would never choose Spitzenkandidat from these countries. This would mean that some countries would never have a president of the commission from their ranks, unless they change their national election laws, which would be a horrible overreach of power.
Second, the winning party of EU elections is still a minority. There is no guarantee that the winning party's candidate is the overall top preference of the parliament, or the people.

What we really need is true presidential elections for the Commission Presidency (using instant-runoff voting), as well as a change in the EU electoral system to allow for true pan-European parties to stand in the parliamentary elections. If parties could run everywhere in the EU no matter where they happen to be based, and if real humans with actual opinions could run directly for the presidency, then we would have much greater transparency, and people across the union would get a much better understanding of who best represent their values.

Fully agree. If anything, this proposal is probably the first thing that should be implemented from the Conference on the   Future of Europe.

Majority voting is indeed one of the first priorities. It should not be seen as a threat by "small" States or as the majority imposing dictates to a minority. It is just a common rule in all democracies, where minority rights are respected. For sure it will not end the good practice of trying to make consensus, but it will avoid to see some members blocking decisions for various reasons, sometimes without relation with the decision to take.

It appears proposals in this spirit have been posted a couple of times on this platform (in varying forms and languages). I guess many people have become frustrated with how idiotic and inept European politics looks on TV when individual countries recurringly indulge in solo-blocking important ideas for entirely unimportant reasons - often unrelated to the actual issue - and assume this isn't transparent to all.
But, like other commenters here, I am dubious such an amendment to end unanimity would pass. Because it requires ... well, unanimity. I agree that a less ambitious start - requiring three or so countries for a veto to become effective, and more after an agreed upon period - seems more reasonable.
Thumbs up on this one, nevertheless. Because the dynamics of political horse-trading need to be changed. A Governments veto to a useful idea, just to press some useless, egoistic interest should not be for free. At least they should be forced to buy themselves some outside support.

I don't know about what kinds of topics should require what types of majorities, but it seems pretty obvious that at the very least the current situation is not sustainable.

The author touched a delicate matter, the fight between generations, actually.
I think this is about new generations trying to have their say but they're blocked by older generations which, in turn, makes the newer generation feel excluded and they start exhibiting weird and aggressive behaviors.
And in my tenure as a people manager, for some time I felt like it was the boomers who were an issue. But after years and years of working with people both above and below me, I came to a striking conclusion - it is actually the Generation X, especially the so called Xennials are the worst.
Xennials are the people who are now in their mid-40s and mid-50s and trust me when I say they are the worst. They are basically the kids no one really had time for, being born between 1970 - 1980, they caught the full-blown Cold War between West and East, they were raised in a culture of doubt, aggressiveness and selfishness. Xennials always tend to work behind the back and suppress younger initiatives.

Although most people identify me as a hipster myself, I can't say I'm a neo-marxist.

But there are also the "normal" hipsters - like me and many friends of mine - let's say we're just a little bit hipsters because, yes, we too think it makes us more authentic and we can digress from the old incumbent in our own way.
While I do like to have a bit of that "Stranger Things" in my general projection of self, I must agree that egalitarian hipsters who actually turn fascist or communist and become aggressive if you don't agree with their general perception, should really be somehow "helped" to better integrate within our society. Alas, nobody wants wars.

Variaton as a guiding perspective and as a structuring principle makes it possible that so many and such different Member States with disparate economies, histories and legal and administrative cultures, work together.

FAEF (Federation Alliance of European Federalists) esta admitiendo miembros con una sola condicion: cada Organizcion siguie trabajando con su programa pero otorga a FAEF el encargo de promover una Federacion Europea.
Desde Octubre 2021 la Convencion de Ciudadanos de FAEF esta trabajando una Constitucion de 10 articulos para la futura Union Europea Federal
En Junio 2022 la Constitucion estara terminada y se hara un Referendum en los Estados europeos. Puede ocurrir:
1) Estados que acepten la Constitucion federal seran los miembros fundadores de la futura Federacion Europea
2) Estados que rechacen la Constitucion se quedaran fuera de la Federacion
Los Estados que hayan rechazado la Constitucion federal podran adherirse mas tarde tal como ocurrio con la Convencion de Filadelfia donde solo 9 Colonias fundaron los Estados Unidos de America, pero posteriormente el resto de las Colonias se unieron a la Federacion.

Unanimity has advantages and disadvantages, as it has qualified majority voting (QMV). Everything depends on what precise/specific/determined legislation we are talking about, in which field/domain/area and at each point in time. In a few words, unanimity sometimes is a hardball to play but sometimes it is essential to transmit a strong union. Therefore, I believe it would be easier and more efficacious if the abolishment of the veto in the Council (veto on unanimity) was made only for certain areas and even sub-areas! For instance, QMV for sanctions (but not for all Foreign affairs), QMV for corporate tax affairs (but not for all economic affairs).

The current inter-governmental and consensual Europe is, de facto, a confederation of national states. It is increasingly becoming marginal, not able to confront aggressive or non-democratic countries in its neighbourhood (Russia, Turkey, Belarus...) or large companies evading its corporate taxes.
A more federal approach, including #NoVeto in favour of Qualified Majority Voting (QMV) is needed for Europe to be effective.
There where QMV is already the rule (Trade, Education, Research), the EU is effective. Vetoes are impeding it to implement policies it started with like minimal corporate taxes or carbon markets.
This goes together, of course, with European Parliament control in these areas, for  a democratic control of the Council deeds.

To Marco Calligaris on Ireland, your point of view doesn't consider that the fiscal rulings negotiated, for example, with Apple, are taxing it effectively at less than 0.01%. How can Apple competitors, often smaller ones, taxed at 20 or 30% compete effectively? It is a competition issue regarding the single market and should be treated as such.

To Marco Calligaris on "big countries" bullying smaller ones. This is what history has been until the European Union was created. Abolishing the veto, goes with democratic control by the European Parliament which should approve the Council QMV decisions. So that if, for example, sanctions are taken against a country, they can weigh the interest of States and Citizen, from all nations.

A universal removal of the veto can backfire badly. If we want to make a lasting Union, we have to reach a compromise. Not by depriving the opposition of any means to oppose and force our will on them.  We must start a real  unification process. 
We currently have only the currency and a market in common, but 27 distinctive armies, police forces, education systems, tax system, laws systems, etc. This has to change by merging everything into a single, EU version/formula of it. The veto should be retained only for matters that are irrelevant to the very existence and operational functionality of the EU. E.g. One can't veto the adoption of the Common  EU education system (Standardization of the teaching classes, education time, grading system, teaching contents), but can veto the introduction of things like "mandatory LGBT class" (It can be facultative, but not mandatory). And so on for other domestic matters that aren't EU businesses.

I do not agree with Presidentialism in general, so I can't support this. Though I can definitely support a parliament with legislative power that votes a symbolic head of state from the European Council, if you really need a president.

I don't think that direction election of a president makes the system "presidential", so the comparison to USA or other presidential systems is misleading. Von Der Leyen was not elected democratically, but she is extremely competent and I don't think that we could do better with direct elections. Already some 20 years ago I started to write up a business case for a European broadcaster. The reason for this is that when I started pitching EU centric content and concepts to Dutch broadcasters they did not show any interest as their main objective was/is to serve Dutch audience with Dutch content or buy (cheap) content from the USA/UK instead of producing national.
The number of concepts/ formats that can be produced and are fit for such a EU wide channel/platform are literally infinite. Just as a reminder: 180 million Europeans watch at least one Eurovision song contest final. 
So basically the idea would be like: how would a single produced Weekend Millionaire show would look like with contestants from all EU countries ? I would watch. This is a format adaptation but you can imagine hundreds of original formats (entertainment, documentaires, reality shows, games, series) produced in English and translated in different languages.

Part: I even pitched this idea to the EBU back then but they redirected me back to the national broadcasters as they fund the EBU.

Part  1: Just a pitch of a European Centric format fit for television that popped up today. It's called 'Eurodrop' and centred around cross border interaction between the 27 EU member states. It's a 'what if' concept.
What if we drop social media influencers or social media stars from each country in a foreign EU capital city. They do not know in which city they are dropped until they remove their headsets and blindfolds. They only have some Euro's and their mobile phone. 
They need to test the knowledge of the foreign country they are dropped about their native country via a dinner. Which country will open the doors first ? (And can win points in the first round). In the second round (once he/she gets invited) the social media stars can ask questions to the hosts by which a country can win additional points.

Part 2:  A question can be: Who is the prime minister of my country ? Another question can be: what is the capital city of my country ? Another question can be: is prostitution legal in my country ? Or: how many people (in millions) live in my country ?
These are some sample questions and maybe you have other questions you think of to ask about your country.
The score of the first and second round will be added and we have a winner of a show.
As we have 27 EU member states we can do 27 episodes. 
So the show is about having fun about our cultural differences and maybe even learn a bit about each other.
I think it's a really important thing to do. It can strenghten the European ties and show the people of Europe that we're all together as one.
this would be good for the european project ( reporting on european projects and issues) and promoting unity while also keeping democracy alive. I dont see why this isnt already a thing

I fully agree that English should no longer be used as the main working language in Europe and especially the European institutions.
However, in my view, a better common language would be one that relates to Europe's identity, history and culture, and is also still present in schools, monuments, churches, etc. This language is Latin -- our common language for 2000 years.
Classical Latin is of course a bit difficult to learn, which puts Esperanto at an advantage thanks to its simplicity. However, a European initiative (led by the Latina Academia: https://latina.ac/en/) has resurrected Latin in a modern form, called "Modern Latin". It is important to note that Modern Latin is very easy to learn (i.e. you can be fluent in a year) and it is a truly European language, and as such would be a great initiative to unite European citizens and reinforce democracy.

The ETUC proposal is of strategic importance. Let us remember that the EU has set itself the ambitious target of having at least 60% of adults in training each year by 2030. IndustriAll European Trade Union supports the ETUC proposal. We have recently adopted a new position paper on ‚ÄôEnsuring lifelong employability through training for future-proof occupational pathways‚Äô : https://news.industriall-europe.eu/Article/595
Every worker must have the right to quality training and life-long learning. This right must be combined with future-proof occupational pathways to support the transitions between jobs and respond to the skills needs resulting from a rapidly transforming industry. Both are a must at the level of employment and labour market policies in order to fight unemployment, and to support virtuous competitiveness and social cohesion. Skills development is a shared responsibility between governments, employers, workers and their trade unions. Our demands towards each are listed in our position paper : https://news.industriall-europe.eu/Article/595

Very important! As the labour market in the EU changes fast, workers should be able to adapt and prepare for this. Acces to the right training is the key to make this happen, so let's make the EPSR target for 2030 a reality.

FNV agrees with this. Not only should people have the right to inclusive and quality education, training and lifelong learning, but also the access to high quality education and development. In this regard it is especially important that tailor-made offers are in line with the qualities and possibilities of workers and job seekers, as well as possibilities for study leave and to be able to receive training during working hours. People themselves should be in charge of their own career development. To reach this, a personal development budget, independent career advice and support are crucial. Trade unions can play an important role in this because they stand next to the employee and have the confidence of workers. We believe that all people should have the opportunity to continue learning: to adjust when changing employment, but also to develop optimally within their current job and to strengthen their labour market position.

The world of work is quickly developing around us, with digitalization, innovation and sustainability adaptation at its core. To be able to measure up with this development, employees must be provided with training and professional development to keep up with innovation and change, as well as to strengthen their employability. This is a key issue for NFU, as a representative of the employees in the Nordic finance sectors. The conference should therefore address the necessity to ensure that lifelong learning and the right to training become a reality for everyone in Europe.

In all fields of education children start by developing an understanding of the basics, then gradually build on that knowledge to tackle more and more complex problems and situations. Teaching Esperanto to children as their first foreign language gives them an understanding of the basic structure of human language. They gain that knowledge through using a language that is regular and logical, one that shows them how languages function and allows them to play and be creative with language in a meaningful way. The time needed for them to be able to communicate complex thoughts and ideas in Esperanto is much shorter than with other languages, giving them an early positive experience of language learning and the ability to communicate in a meaningful way with others.
This positive grounding stands them in good stead if they wish to go on and tackle other languages more complex and irregular in their structure. It gives them the tools they need to truly succeed as language learners!

Maybe it's not entirely clear why we want the official recognition of Esperanto or why we consider that EU does not give full recognition to Esperanto as a language of european citizens.
Just have a look on the EU page "EU languages", https://europa.eu/european-union/about-eu/eu-languages_en . There is an explanation about official languages and about "Regional & minority languages" - but Esperanto is not mentioned.
Maybe you'll think that Esperanto is the language of a minority - yes, but Esperanto is not a "minority language" following the "European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages" of the Council of Europe, https://www.coe.int/en/web/conventions/full-list/-/conventions/rms/0900001680695175 . Esperanto does not fit into the definition there, because it is not "traditionally used within a given territory of a State". Esperanto exists only since 1887, not enough for "traditionally". So when characterizing the language situation of the EU Esperanto has to be mentioned.

Lakes are sensitive ecosystems providing essential ecosystem services and hotspots of biodiversity. They need special care and efforts to achieve sound lake management and sustainable development of the surrounding regions. The EU Commission should put a special focus on lakes and lake regions, e.g. with specific programs to support truly sustainable development and coherent protection.
Marion Hammerl, Lake Constance Foundation

Large lakes are facing specific challenges in relation to regional development, land-use planning, provision of transport services, and adaptation to climate change. One key issue is the balance to be found between tourism/residential development and protection of ecosystems/biodiversity. The ESPON LAKES project (www.espon.eu/lakes) that we recently completed confirms that large lakes could benefit from more integrated perspectives. 
The EU can contribute to solving (part of) these issues especially by convincing Member States of the relevance of using territorial tools (ITIs, CLLDs) in large lake regions to channel EU funds. Also by fostering arenas of exchanges where stakeholders from lake regions all over Europe can share ideas and initiatives.
